At this time, the SCU Lightning Complex fire is only 15% contained. However, the west edge of the fire area has little expectations for moving our way. In the event of a shift, there is quite a bit of distance between MHUSD schools and the current fire line. The 7- day forecast predicts some winds but not strong enough to cause concern. The Emergency Operations Center has removed the evacuation urgency orders for residents in those school areas.

For all those reasons, the evacuation order for Jackson Academy of Math and Music, Live Oak High School, and Nordstrom Elementary, is reversed and staff may return to the sites this afternoon. Principals are working with our Information Technology Department to schedule cancelling the forwarding of phones.

We appreciated everyone's patience and cooperation. We also appreciate the support given to those staff members who were displaced due to their school temporary closures.

https://conta.cc/2UCLKiZ

The YMCA in partnership with MHUSD is providing childcare for essential workers in our communiyt. The program has space for up to 30 children at Barrett Elementary, but the goal is to expand to serve more. The cost to run the program is $300 per child per week, but there are not funds available to subsidize or lower the cost.

Morgan Hill Community Foundation, in partnership with MHUSD and the YMCA, is asking for your help to raise money to cover child care costs for essential workers who may not have childcare. With your support, not only can we help lower child care costs, we will be able to expand this program to provide access for more children and open it to all essential workers in these unprecedented times.

Please either visit our website or follow this link for more information and to donate today: https://conta.cc/2UCLKiZ

Twelve MHUSD schools were recognized for their dedication to the implementation of Positive Behavior Interventions and Supports (PBIS). In order to achieve recognition by the California PBIS Coalition, a school is rated in 7 areas of PBIS implementation: 1.) Effectively teach appropriate behavior to all children; 2.) Intervene early; 3.) Use of a multi-tier model of service delivery; 4.) Use research-based, scientifically validated interventions to the extent available; 5.) Monitor student progress to inform interventions; 6.) Use data to make decisions, and 7.) Use assessment for three different purposes.

Congratulations to both El Toro Health Science Academy and Nordstrom Elementary School for achieving Gold Level in the PBIS recognitions awards system. Principals McDonald and Grove received their school banners at the Board meeting tonight. Superintendent Betando also thanked Michele Bergeron for her hard work in implementing the program. #PBIS #MTSS #education #morganhill

February 9 at 5:30 PM ·

Currently the health risk to the general public in Santa Clara County from novel coronavirus remains low, but we encourage everyone to take common-sense precautions to prevent the spread of all infectious diseases, including common illnesses like colds and flu:

• Stay home if you are sick.

• If you have a fever stay home and remain there for at least 24 hours after you no longer have a fever without the use of fever-reducing medicine.

• Wash your hands with liquid soap and water, rub for at least 20 seconds.

• Avoid touching your face, particularly your eyes, nose, and mouth.

• Cough or sneeze into a tissue, sleeve, or arm. Do not use your hands.

• Perform routine surface cleaning, particularly for high-touch surfaces.

• Consider not attending or hosting large gatherings if you are not feeling well.

The Public Health Department has a webpage dedicated to novel coronavirus in English, Chinese, Spanish, and Vietnamese at https://sccphd.org/coronavirus

Save the date: April 1, 2020 is Census Day.

Why should we participate in the Census?

1) More affordable housing: Counting everyone will help demonstrate our housing shortage and win funding to fix it.

2) Stronger schools: A full count will help fund our schools and improve programs for our students.

3) Safer neighborhoods: An accurate count will help first responders plan for emergencies and secure the funding to face them.

4) Better healthcare: A complete count will help improve our health policies and fund the health care services we need.

5) When we all get counted, we stand up for our values and we stand firm against anyone who would try to silence our voices.

California schools receive over $7 billion in federal funding, which is impacted by complete and accurate census count. The Census is confidential.

Happy Friday, everyone!!

post_text: Tonight, the Morgan Hill Community was invited to tour the new Lewis H. Britton Middle School campus. City staff, elected officials, former Board of Education members, teachers, parents, students and more were able to explore the new areas of the renovated campus which was opened up especially for this event. Superintendent Steve Betando, Director of Construction Casino Fajardo and members of the Facilities and Construction teams led the visitors through the classrooms, answering questions along the way.
